div.p: The construction of the LA Aqueduct in 1913 marked the transition of San Fernando and the surrounding cities into citrus suburbs. These Citrusburbs or “Agroburbs” were characterized as semi rural areas that utilized the technological innovations of the aqueduct and railroads to build an agricultural economy. Anglo settlers attempted to impose an idealized utopian agricultural settlement. Garcia states, “...agricultural settlement was universally recognized as the line separating civilization from savagery”(21). Previous settlement of Mexican people was focused on ranching economy. However, new settlement sought to impose a garden citrus utopia that was popular imagery for Southern California boosters. This new settlement produced profitable citrus industries that required Mexican American and immigrant labor to operate. As Garcia remarks, “labor transformed the ‘landscape’ both physically and culturally– of a region…”(19). This transformation was a major impact on Mexican community living conditions and redefined their social status in the San Fernando Valley.

note.p: Technological innovation of LA aqueduct and railroad systems facilitated new suburban developments based on citrus economy in San Fernando.
